content.description: It's frequently asserted that emergencies are best addressed by powerful executives; there is also the view that executives might suspend normal legal provisions and adhere to special rules designed for an exception or operate in a legal vacuum. Challenges posed by this liberal democracy has been debated extensively with respect to the global war on terror; the 2020 pandemic has prompted new questions as to what happens to the separation of powers and fundamental rights when executives address a health emergency; less obviously, has also been the concern that executive failure might amount to a violation of a fundamental right to health.
content.name: Executives and Emergencies: Normative, Legal, and Empirical Transatlantic Perspectives (Half-Term)
